sen.j: 遊女（ゆうじょ、あそびめ）とは、遊郭や宿場で男性に性的サービスをした娼婦で、「客を遊ばせる女性｣と言う意味が一般的である。
sen.e: Yujo or Asobime was a prostitute who did sexual service to men at yukaku (prostitute quarters) or a posting station, and the meaning of yujo is generally considered 'a woman who has her guest make merry.'

sen.j: 「遊女」という呼称は古くからあり、元来、芸能に従事する女性一般を指したものであり、とりたてて売春専業者を意味するものではなかった。
sen.e: The naming of 'yujo' had existed since old times, and it originally referred to the women in general who were engaged in the performing arts, so it did not necessarily mean prostitute only.

sen.e: For example, the Sarashina Diary has a description in which a traveling party including the author in her girlhood appreciated singing of yujo in the lodging at the foot of Mt. Ashigara.

sen.j: 古来より数多くの呼称があり、古く『万葉集』には、遊行女婦（うかれめ）の名で書かれており、平安時代になるとこれに代わって遊女（あそび）がでてくる。
sen.e: There has been many names referring to yujo since ancient times; in old "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves), it was called ukareme, and in the Heian period it became asobi instead.

sen.e: During the medieval period, they were called kugutsume, shirabyoshi, keisei, or joro.

sen.j: 近世になると、女郎（じょろう）、遊君（ゆうくん）、娼妓（しょうぎ）といった呼称もあらわれる。
sen.e: In the early-modern times, the names such as joro, yukun, shogi appeared.

sen.j: 太夫は最高位の遊女。

sen.j: 江戸 吉原遊郭では一時期これを特に花魁（おいらん）といった。

sen.j: 湯屋で働く湯女（ゆな）や、旅籠で働く飯盛女（めしもりおんな）はより大衆的な売春婦であった。
sen.e: Yuna, a woman who worked for a bathhouse, and meshimori onna, a woman who worked for a inn were more lowbrow prostitute.

sen.j: 奈良期から平安期における遊女の主たる仕事は、神仏一致の遊芸による伝播であり、その後遊芸伝承が次第に中心となる。
sen.e: The main work of yujo from the Nara to the Heian periods was to spread the art for amusement in synthesis of Buddhism and Shinto, and later it gradually came to spread the art for amusement only.

sen.j: 日本に於いては、母系婚が鎌倉初期まで続いた事は論を俟たないが、男系相続の進展と共に、母系の婚家に男が通う形態から、まず、別宅としての男性主体の住処が成立した。
sen.e: In Japan, it is a matter of course that matrilineal marriage lasted until the early Kamakura period, but as succession in the male line became common, a man hardly came to visit his spouse's family, but came to have his own residence as a second house.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: その結果、そこに侍る女性としての性行為を前提とする新たな女性層が生まれる。
sen.e: As a result, a new class of women who served such second house on condition that they had a sexual act with their master came into existence.

sen.j: これは、原始から綿々と続いた、子孫繁栄のための対等な性行為から、性行為自体を商品化する大きな転機となる。
sen.e: This formed a big turning point for putting a sexual act itself on the market from the equivalent sexual act for fertility and family prosperity, which had lasted since the primitive period.

sen.j: それまで、財産は母系、位階は夫系であった秩序が壊れた。
sen.e: Until then, there had been an order in which property belonged to the wife's family, and ikai (court rank) was handed down in the husband's family.

sen.j: 自立する拠り所を失った女性が、生活のために性行為を行う「売春」が発生するのは、正にこの時期である。
sen.e: It is exactly this period of time when women who lost a support for independence became a 'prostitute' for living.

sen.e: Asobime was distinguished from such women, and they performed a sexual act as a part of light accomplishments.

sen.e: Then they heightened a sexual act itself to the art of amusement, and yujo, as a professional group of prostitutes, was established.

sen.j: 売春婦は俗に世界最古の職業と言われるが、日本の遊女も古くから存在していた。
sen.e: Prostitute is commonly called the oldest profession in the world, and Japanese yujo also existed since old times.

sen.j: 諸外国の神殿娼婦と同様、日本の遊女もかつては神社で巫女として神に仕えながら歌や踊りを行っていた。
sen.e: As well as prostitutes in a sanctuary in various foreign countries, Japanese yujo once sang and danced in the shrine, serving a god as a shrine maiden.

sen.j: しかし、後に神社を去って諸国を漂泊し、宿場や港で歌や踊りをしながら一方で性も売る様になったものと思われる。
sen.e: However, it is considered that later they came to leave the shrine and wander around various areas, singing and dancing at the posting station and a harbor, meanwhile they also sold sexual acts.

sen.e: On the one hand, there are some scholars who think that yujo had something to do with 'gijo' (music-playing women) in 'Naikyobo,' a training center of Imperial dancing and music.

sen.e: During the Heian period, the word, 'yujo,' came into existence, and especially yujo in Eguchi and Kanzaki region (Amagasaki City), which had flourished for water transport of Osaka Bay and Yodo-gawa Water System, were known.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には白拍子・宿々の遊君といった遊女が現れたが、鎌倉幕府・室町幕府も遊女を取り締まり、税を徴収した。
sen.e: During the Kamakura period, yujo such as shirabyoshi and shukushuku no yukun appeared, but both Kamakura and Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) exercised strict control over yujo and collected taxes.

sen.e: In the early-modern times, prostitute houses were gathered in one place in the city and yukaku was formed.

sen.j: 1584年（天正13年）、豊臣秀吉の治世に、今の大阪の道頓堀川北岸に最初の遊廓がつくられた。
sen.e: In 1584, during the reign of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, the first yukaku was built at the north bank of the present Dotonbori-gawa River in Osaka.

sen.j: その5年後（1589年 天正17年）には、京都柳町に遊廓が作られた。
sen.e: Five years later (1589), yukaku was established at Kyoto Yanagimachi.

sen.j: 徳川幕府は江戸に1612年（慶長17年）日本橋人形町付近に吉原遊廓を設けた。
sen.e: In 1612, the Tokugawa bakufu built Yoshiwara yukaku near Ningyo-cho, Nihonbashi in Edo.

sen.j: 17世紀前半に、大坂の遊郭を新町（新町遊廓）へ、京都柳町の遊郭を朱雀野（島原遊廓）に移転した他、吉原遊廓を最終的に浅草日本堤付近に移転した。
sen.e: During the first half of the 17th century, yukaku in Osaka was moved to Shinmachi (Shinmachi yukaku), and Kyoto Yanagimachi yukaku was to Shujakano (Shimabara yukaku); besides Yoshiwara yukaku was moved to near Nihonzutsumi, Asakusa in the end.

sen.j: 島原、新町、吉原が公許の三大遊郭（大阪・新町のかわりに長崎・丸山、伊勢・古市を入れる説もある）であったが、ほかにも全国20数カ所に公許の遊廓が存在し、各宿場にも飯盛女と言われる娼婦がいた。
sen.e: Although Shimabara, Shinmachi, and Yoshiwara were three big yukaku (there is also an opinion that Nagasaki Maruyama and Ise Furuichi are included instead of Osaka Shinmachi), there were twenty and more licensed yukaku all over Japan, and prostitutes called meshimori onna were at each post stations.

sen.j: 1873年（明治6年）、芸娼妓解放令が出されたが、娼婦が自由意思で営業しているというたてまえになっただけで、前借金に縛られた境遇という実態は変わらなかった。
sen.e: In 1873, the emancipation of prostitute act was issued, but it was only claimed in theory that prostitutes worked by their free will, and the actual condition that they were in the circumstances of being over head and ears in debt was not changed.

sen.j: 1946年に連合国軍最高司令官総司令部の指令により遊郭は廃止され赤線に看板を変えるが、これも1958年売春防止法の施行によりいったんは消滅した。
sen.e: In 1946, yukaku were abolished by order of the General Headquarters of the Allied Powers (GHQ) and red-light districts appeared instead, but Anti-Prostitution Law went into effect in 1958 and they also disappeared temporarily.

sen.e: A part of yujo in the Edo period were women who had been sold from a pander, but most of the high ranking yujo were born to a red-light district or the family of light accomplishments; of such girls, those who were bright and beautiful since they were young were trained as kaburo (child attendants of prostitutes).

sen.e: Most of them went into service for about ten years, and when their terms were up, they were set free.
Most of them went into service for about ten years, and when their terms were up, they were set free.

sen.j: しかし、それ以前に身請されて結婚、あるいは囲われる者も多く、また一部はやり手、縫い子となり、一生を廓の中で過ごす者も存在した。
sen.e: Though, there were many yujo who were redeemed and got married or kept by a man; there were also some yujo who became yarite (female managers) or nuiko (literally, a girl who sews), spending their whole life in the red-light district.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Though, there were many yujo who were redeemed and got married or kept by a man; there were also some yujo who became yarite (female managers) or nuiko (literally, a girl who sews), spending their whole life in the red-light district.

Though, there were many yujo who were redeemed and got married or kept by a man; there were also some yujo who became yarite (female managers) or nuiko (literally, a girl who sews), spending their whole life in the red-light district.

sen.j: ただし嶋原の太夫は体を売らなかったので芸妓であって遊女ではないともいわれる。
sen.e: However, it is said that Tayu in Shimabara was not yujo but geigi because they did not have sexual relationships with their guests.
However, it is said that Tayu in Shimabara was not yujo but geigi because they did not have sexual relationships with their guests.
However, it is said that Tayu in Shimabara was not yujo but geigi because they did not have sexual relationships with their guests.

sen.j: 新吉原での名称
sen.e: A name in Shin Yoshiwara (a red-light district)

A name in Shin Yoshiwara (a red-light district)

sen.j: (一人前の遊女。お歯黒を付けるが引眉しない)
sen.e: (Grown-up yujo who applied tooth black but did not paint brows.)
sen.cmt: 2つに分かれていたセルを統合。
sen.e: (Grown-up yujo who applied tooth black but did not paint brows.)
(Grown-up yujo who applied tooth black but did not paint brows.)

sen.j: 太夫 (遊郭)（最上位の女郎、宝暦年間の頃には自然消滅する）
sen.e: Tayu (yukaku) (The highest ranking prostitute who died a natural death during the Horeki era.)
Tayu (yukaku) (The highest ranking prostitute died a natural death during the Horeki era (1753-1764).)
sen.cmt: who died → died原文にはありませんが宝暦年間の説明として(1753-1764).を追加しました。
sen.e: Tayu (yukaku) (The highest ranking prostitute died a natural death during the Horeki era (1753-1764).)

sen.j: 現在では法律上遊女は存在しないが、遊郭の伝統の一部は観光資源として保存され、定期観光バスや和風テーマパーク、および各地の祭りで見る事が出来る
sen.e: Today yujo does not exist legally, but a part of yukaku's tradition has been preserved as tourism resources, and you can see them in a tourist bus that operates on a fixed schedule, or at Japanese style theme parks and festivals all over Japan.

Today yujo does not exist legally, but a part of yukaku's tradition has been preserved as tourism resources, which can be seen in a tourist bus tour that operates on a fixed schedule, or at Japanese style theme parks and festivals all over Japan.
sen.cmt: 観光バスの車内ではなくて ﾊﾞｽツアーの中でということなので tourを追加し、表現も修正しました。
sen.e: Today yujo does not exist legally, but a part of yukaku's tradition has been preserved as tourism resources, which can be seen in a tourist bus tour that operates on a fixed schedule, or at Japanese style theme parks and festivals all over Japan.

sen.e: At Japan Old Kimono Museum, many kimono which were worn in the oiran dochu processions from the Edo to the Meiji periods are displayed
